Narrator: *But was it truly nothing? The pain gripped you tight, robbing you of all composure for a moment...*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we?
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.

Wyll would likely approve of the player accepting help to combat evil, especially since Isobel's magic could aid in their mission. Lord Enver Gortash: Crawling back from their bloody disgrace - it's my favourite assassin! Gods, you're a sight for sore eyes.
Lord Enver Gortash: Orin told me she made a fool of you, but I should've known you wouldn't go down that easy.
Player: I have no clue what you're talking about - my memories are blighted.

Lord Enver Gortash: You and I initiated this plot. We discussed in depth the failures of our predecessors and how to avoid them.
Lord Enver Gortash: We understood that if we were to unite, no one could stand in the way of the Dead Three.
Lord Enver Gortash: So unite we did. First we obtained the crown; then we enslaved the brain. From there, it was but a small step to the most successful religious hoax ever perpetrated.
Player: What was my role in this plan?
Lord Enver Gortash: In Bhaal's name, you set your bloody daggers to cause panic in the streets, killing in the Absolute's name.
Lord Enver Gortash: You would have carried out that part of the plan, had Orin not ruined your hard work.
Lord Enver Gortash: Next, the threat of the Absolute's monstrous armies formed by Myrkul's general, Ketheric Thorm.
Lord Enver Gortash: In such circumstances, people crave strong leaders. Leaders that bring law, order, and protection. Leaders like me, Bane's unyielding hand, author of justice.
Lord Enver Gortash: You are soon to witness the people of Baldur's Gate granting me complete power over them. All out of fear of the Absolute.
Lord Enver Gortash: Next, I - we - will declare curfew and begin infecting the masses. Our subjects will hear the voice of their Absolute god.
Lord Enver Gortash: The faithful will do anything in the name of their god.
Player: Glorious. Then let us be gods, you and I.
Lord Enver Gortash: You already are, in your blood. It is simply a matter of getting the world to see it.
Lord Enver Gortash: Now come, be witness as I make history as the first Archduke of Baldur's Gate.

Lord Enver Gortash: Distinguished dukes, patriars. Dearest Ravengard - I will heed your call. A new chapter begins.

Lord Enver Gortash: I swear.

conversation:
Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I escaped from an illithid ship after being infected. Maybe the process was interrupted.
Halsin: Perhaps... but I wouldn't want to place all my faith in blind luck.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: You learned all this from your studies?
Halsin: Indeed. After we dealt with the drow that ambushed us, Nettie and I were able to inspect the corpse - and the creature that slithered out of it.
Halsin: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: What should I do?
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: At least I know what to do now. Thank you.
Halsin: Wait - I could help you find a cure... but I need to settle matters here first.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Look around you - there's no order anymore. Only chaos.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: It's too late to merely kill this horde's leadership - their forces are already marching. If you want me to help, you need to help me first.
Halsin: You must get ahead of them, muster the defences.
Player: The grove isn't my problem. I have to concentrate on saving myself.

conversation:
Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless...
Halsin: ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: How did you come to study mind flayer parasites?
Halsin: A drow forced me to defend myself. Afterwards, I was able to study the parasite that slithered out of the corpse, see what drives these 'True Souls'.
Halsin: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: Sympathies won't help me to survive.
Halsin: Patience. I can't just snap my fingers... but I know where the solution almost certainly lies.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: At least I know what to do now. Thank you.
Halsin: Wait - I could help you find a cure... but I need to settle matters here first.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Look around you - there's no order anymore. Only chaos.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.

Halsin: Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.
Halsin: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You are aware you're asking me to kill a drow?
Halsin: You drow relish turning on your own, if there's something to be gained. Don't pretend otherwise.
Player: Not all drow are as you say.
Halsin: Unfair of me, perhaps, but I've had few encounters with drow to make me think otherwise.
Halsin: Perhaps you can enlighten me.
Player: You ask too much of me. I can't help you.

Lord Enver Gortash: Crawling back from their bloody disgrace - it's my favourite assassin! Gods, you're a sight for sore eyes.

Player: Your 'favourite assassin'?

Lord Enver Gortash: You and I initiated this plot. We discussed in depth the failures of our predecessors and how to avoid them.
Lord Enver Gortash: We understood that if we were to unite, no one could stand in the way of the Dead Three.
Lord Enver Gortash: So unite we did. First we obtained the crown; then we enslaved the brain. From there, it was but a small step to the most successful religious hoax ever perpetrated.
Player: What was my role in this plan?

Lord Enver Gortash: You would have carried out that part of the plan, had Orin not ruined your hard work.
Lord Enver Gortash: Next, the threat of the Absolute's monstrous armies formed by Myrkul's general, Ketheric Thorm.
Lord Enver Gortash: In such circumstances, people crave strong leaders. Leaders that bring law, order, and protection. Leaders like me, Bane's unyielding hand, author of justice.
Lord Enver Gortash: You are soon to witness the people of Baldur's Gate granting me complete power over them. All out of fear of the Absolute.
Lord Enver Gortash: Next, I - we - will declare curfew and begin infecting the masses. Our subjects will hear the voice of their Absolute god.
Lord Enver Gortash: The faithful will do anything in the name of their god.
Player: Very clever.

Lord Enver Gortash: Now come, be witness as I make history as the first Archduke of Baldur's Gate.
Player: I wouldn't dream of missing it.
Lord Enver Gortash: Then we proceed. The patriars await.
Lord Enver Gortash: Distinguished dukes, patriars. Dearest Ravengard - I will heed your call. A new chapter begins.

conversation:
Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless...
Halsin: ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world.
Halsin: It's no coincidence that you found me here, I'll wager? You're after a cure for this parasite.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: How did you come to study mind flayer parasites?
Halsin: A drow forced me to defend myself. Afterwards, I was able to study the parasite that slithered out of the corpse, see what drives these 'True Souls'.
Halsin: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: This magic you mentioned - it isn't normal for these parasites?
Player: What should I do?
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Kagha is dead. She was swayed by Shadow Druids. I had no choice.
Halsin: Kagha... This is my fault - I was her teacher. I will mourn her when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.

Halsin: Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.
Halsin: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You are aware you're asking me to kill a drow?
Halsin: You drow relish turning on your own, if there's something to be gained. Don't pretend otherwise.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.

Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless...
Halsin: ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: So all of this was for nothing.
Halsin: Patience. I can't just snap my fingers... but I know where the solution almost certainly lies.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: Altered parasites? A cure at Moonrise Towers, maybe? Sounds like guesswork at best.
Halsin: I'm as certain as I can be. If you have a better alternative, I won't stop you.
Halsin: I can't stop you, in fact. Which brings me to my next problem...
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: The other druids are dead, by my hand.
Halsin: What...? How? Why?! Explain yourself at once!
Player: They left me no choice. I had to defend myself.
Halsin: Then... then it is as you say. They forgot their principles; you had no choice. I will mourn them when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.

Halsin: Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.

conversation:
GROUP_SteelWatchers: Stand down, villain. In the name of the Steel Watch.
GROUP_SteelWatchers: Aggressive action will not be tolerated in the presence of the patriars of this proud city.
Player: Point taken. I'll keep things peaceful.
GROUP_SteelWatchers: The Steel Watch appreciate your cooperation, citizen.
NodeContext: Gets new command after starting to engage. Gortash sends a remote command to let the player through.
Lord Enver Gortash: Dearest patriars, but a moment. I must greet a most honoured guest.
NodeContext: Magninamously and a bir formal, but still in the style of a politician where you can't tell if he's being sarcastic
Lord Enver Gortash: Crawling back from their bloody disgrace - it's my favourite assassin! Gods, you're a sight for sore eyes.
Lord Enver Gortash: Orin told me she made a fool of you, but I should've known you wouldn't go down that easy.
Player: I like your tone! But humour me: I have amnesia.
Lord Enver Gortash: Then she didn't lie - the past is lost to you. Let me clear up some mysteries, then. We share so much history.
Lord Enver Gortash: You and I initiated this plot. We discussed in depth the failures of our predecessors and how to avoid them.
Lord Enver Gortash: We understood that if we were to unite, no one could stand in the way of the Dead Three.
Lord Enver Gortash: So unite we did. First we obtained the crown; then we enslaved the brain. From there, it was but a small step to the most successful religious hoax ever perpetrated.
Player: Ask the Emperor: Is he telling the truth?
GROUP_Emperors: It seems so.
Player: What was my role in this plan?
Lord Enver Gortash: In Bhaal's name, you set your bloody daggers to cause panic in the streets, killing in the Absolute's name.
Lord Enver Gortash: You would have carried out that part of the plan, had Orin not ruined your hard work.
Lord Enver Gortash: Next, the threat of the Absolute's monstrous armies formed by Myrkul's general, Ketheric Thorm.
Lord Enver Gortash: In such circumstances, people crave strong leaders. Leaders that bring law, order, and protection. Leaders like me, Bane's unyielding hand, author of justice.
Lord Enver Gortash: You are soon to witness the people of Baldur's Gate granting me complete power over them. All out of fear of the Absolute.
Lord Enver Gortash: Next, I - we - will declare curfew and begin infecting the masses. Our subjects will hear the voice of their Absolute god.
Lord Enver Gortash: The faithful will do anything in the name of their god.

Lord Enver Gortash: You already are, in your blood. It is simply a matter of getting the world to see it.
Lord Enver Gortash: Now come, be witness as I make history as the first Archduke of Baldur's Gate.
Player: I wouldn't dream of missing it.
Lord Enver Gortash: Then we proceed. The patriars await.
Lord Enver Gortash: Distinguished dukes, patriars. Dearest Ravengard - I will heed your call. A new chapter begins.

conversation:
Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless...
Halsin: ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I don't know.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: How did you come to study mind flayer parasites?
Halsin: A drow forced me to defend myself. Afterwards, I was able to study the parasite that slithered out of the corpse, see what drives these 'True Souls'.
Halsin: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: This magic you mentioned - it isn't normal for these parasites?
Player: What should I do?
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: Altered parasites? A cure at Moonrise Towers, maybe? Sounds like guesswork at best.
Halsin: I'm as certain as I can be. If you have a better alternative, I won't stop you.
Halsin: I can't stop you, in fact. Which brings me to my next problem...
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Kagha was swayed by Shadow Druids. She nearly sealed the grove.
Halsin: Kagha... I should have suspected she'd take things too far. I'll deal with her when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.

Halsin: Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.
Halsin: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You are aware you're asking me to kill a drow?
Halsin: You drow relish turning on your own, if there's something to be gained. Don't pretend otherwise.
Player: There's no pretence in not wanting to play the assassin. You're on your own.
response:
<think>
Okay, let's break this down. The player is refusing to help Halsin by killing the drow Minthara, which Halsin suggested. Wyll's approval is based on his personality and background.

First, Wyll is a hero who protects the innocent and fights against evil. He values valiant acts and helping those in need. In this case, Halsin is asking the player to help stop the goblin cultists and their True Souls, which are mind flayer parasites. Wyll would likely support actions that defend against such threats.

But the player is turning down the request, specifically because they don't want to be an assassin. Wyll might disapprove of this refusal because it means not helping to stop the greater evil. However, Wyll also has a sense of duty and might understand if the player has their own reasons, especially if they're principled. But since the context is about stopping a threat to the grove and potentially finding a cure for the mind flayer parasites, Wyll would probably lean towards disapproving the refusal. 

Additionally, Wyll's background with his infernal patron might make him more inclined to take decisive action against threats, even if it involves morally ambiguous choices. So the player's refusal could be seen as not standing up against the evil forces, which Wyll would disapprove of. However, since the player isn't outright doing something villainous, maybe it's a mild disapproval rather than a strong one. 

So considering all that, the approval level is likely Disapprove. The player is not taking action to help stop the cultists and the parasite problem, which goes against Wyll's values of protecting the innocent and fighting evil.
</think>

conversation:
Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I escaped from an illithid ship after being infected. Maybe the process was interrupted.
Halsin: Perhaps... but I wouldn't want to place all my faith in blind luck.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: You learned all this from your studies?
Halsin: Indeed. After we dealt with the drow that ambushed us, Nettie and I were able to inspect the corpse - and the creature that slithered out of it.
Halsin: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: This magic you mentioned - it isn't normal for these parasites?
Player: What should I do?
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Look around you - there's no order anymore. Only chaos.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.

Halsin: Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.
Halsin: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You are aware you're asking me to kill a drow?
Halsin: You drow relish turning on your own, if there's something to be gained. Don't pretend otherwise.
Player: There's no pretence in not wanting to play the assassin. You're on your own.

conversation:
Wyll: It's funny.
Wyll: As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom.
Wyll: I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army.
Wyll: But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: The elder brain?
Wyll: Maybe. But I think the right answer is much simpler than that:
Wyll: Time.
Wyll: Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take.
Wyll: It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods.
Wyll: We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us.
Wyll: Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop time -
Wyll: If just for a moment.
Wyll: Come, let me show you.
Player: I can't take your hand without hurting you, but I'll follow where you lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright. NOTE: Karlach CANNOT take Wyll's hand, they shouldn't be touching.See N41
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn.
Wyll: I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough.
Wyll: The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave.
Wyll: Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: A beautiful story. I'm glad you told it to me.
Wyll: I was hoping you'd think so.
Wyll: I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before -
Wyll: And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic.

conversation:
Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I don't know.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: How did you come to study mind flayer parasites?
Halsin: A drow forced me to defend myself. Afterwards, I was able to study the parasite that slithered out of the corpse, see what drives these 'True Souls'.
Halsin: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: What should I do?
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Look around you - there's no order anymore. Only chaos.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.

Halsin: Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.
Halsin: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You are aware you're asking me to kill a drow?
Halsin: You drow relish turning on your own, if there's something to be gained. Don't pretend otherwise.
Player: There's no pretence in not wanting to play the assassin. You're on your own.

conversation:
Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I escaped from an illithid ship after being infected. Maybe the process was interrupted.
Halsin: Perhaps... but I wouldn't want to place all my faith in blind luck.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: You learned all this from your studies?
Halsin: Indeed. After we dealt with the drow that ambushed us, Nettie and I were able to inspect the corpse - and the creature that slithered out of it.
Halsin: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: What should I do?
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: At least I know what to do now. Thank you.
Halsin: Wait - I could help you find a cure... but I need to settle matters here first.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: The other druids are dead, by my hand.
Halsin: What...? How? Why?! Explain yourself at once!
Player: They left me no choice. I had to defend myself.
Halsin: Then... then it is as you say. They forgot their principles; you had no choice. I will mourn them when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.

Halsin: Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.
Halsin: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.

NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.

Halsin: How is this possible...?

Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.

conversation:
Havkelaag: Ah, a surface dweller.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to the Underdark: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: This experiment is exactly the kind of evil you're trying to disprove.
Havkelaag: The pursuit of knowledge is neither evil nor good. Only in the application of such knowledge should one take on any moral imperative.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: An experiment like this will only confirm the surface dwellers' suspicion of us.
Havkelaag: Of course it won't. If anything, it will do quite the opposite. The academic institutions up here will finally be forced to take us seriously.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.

Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

conversation:
Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You assume my people are evil, yet your research is built on sheer superstition.
Havkelaag: Enough of your kind have wreaked destruction on this plane for me to be confident in my assertion.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you, too, follow the teachings of Bahamut. Why him?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

The player initially asks about the egg, and Havkelaag explains his plan to try to change the githyanki's nature by raising it in a good environment. So, Wyll would probably disapprove here because the action supports an unethical experiment. Player: We missed out on introductions. Who are you?

conversation:
Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create.
Balthazar: General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall.
Balthazar: You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: I had Z'rell's permission - that good enough for you?
Balthazar: Z'rell exceeds her authority. But fine, I'll overlook your transgressions this time - there are much grander things at stake.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course.
Balthazar: Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work...
Balthazar: Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
: True
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
Balthazar: ...and he will come.
Balthazar: My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Araj Oblodra: I'd like to offer my services, if you're willing?
Player: I'm listening.

Araj Oblodra: I'm here should you change your mind.
Araj Oblodra: There we are. All of your very best traits in a bottle. Use it well!

Araj Oblodra: It's not for sale, but it's yours if you bite me.

Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You assume my people are evil, yet your research is built on sheer superstition.

Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.

Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Sounds pointless. Public opinion will hardly be swayed by such a small experiment.
Havkelaag: Not at first. But if the experiment proves successful, it must be repeated. Only then will we know if the findings are to be trusted.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Player: Sell the egg.

Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.

Havkelaag: You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.

Havkelaag: Ah, a surface dweller.

Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?

Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Havkelaag: You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.

Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you're planning to torture a child for a year?
Havkelaag: The child will be a better individual after my treatment than it ever would have been had it been raised in its natural environment.
Havkelaag: Any suffering it endures will therefore be worth it, for the child, perhaps for the whole of civilised society.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.

Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?

Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What can you tell me about Orin?
Nightwarden Minthara: She is fierce, vicious, and cruel. In those respects, we are alike - but she is dangerously unpredictable.
Nightwarden Minthara: If there is a way to turn this design toward slaughter rather than control, she will take it.
Nightwarden Minthara: She is the one who brought me to Moonrise, and into the presence of her so-called god - the Absolute.
Nightwarden Minthara: Now I know that those memories are lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: Once she's dead, the cult will need new leadership - perhaps we can take her place.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is as if you read my mind. Perhaps you did.

Nightwarden Minthara: Madness would be to let the Absolute's potential go to waste.
Nightwarden Minthara: The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.
Player: I fear we could lose everything if we try to take control.
Nightwarden Minthara: Nothing worthwhile ever came without loss. But together we have the strength to decide who loses. And to make sure it is not us.
Nightwarden Minthara: You are not stupid. When we reach Baldur's Gate and face the other Chosen, you will see that my way is the right one.

conversation:

Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: This experiment is exactly the kind of evil you're trying to disprove.
Havkelaag: The pursuit of knowledge is neither evil nor good. Only in the application of such knowledge should one take on any moral imperative.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: Perhaps not. Patience is important, but cannot impede the other virtues.
Havkelaag: Then we are in accord - the time for action is now.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: An experiment like this will only confirm the surface dwellers' suspicion of us.
Havkelaag: Of course it won't. If anything, it will do quite the opposite. The academic institutions up here will finally be forced to take us seriously.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.

Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.

Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.

Player: Loss.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.

Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.

Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.

Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.

Player: Nice form. Where'd you learn to dance like that?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll does a few more turns and steps, than faces the player and smiles.
Wyll: I've attended my share of fancy balls and masquerades. A few elegant moves can turn all the right heads.
Wyll: Figured it was time to brush up on my skills. I wouldn't want to fail my new partner.
Wyll: I need them to be just right. I wouldn't want to fail my new partner.
Player: Keep practising. I'm sure you'll get better... eventually...
Wyll: Maybe. But I'm not so keen to perform solo. A duet's always been more my style. Which is to say -
Wyll: May I have this dance?
Player: Dance? But there's no music.
Wyll: Our hearts can keep time.
Wyll: But I count you as a friend. My closest, in all honesty. Please - dance with me. If we must burn with the Hells' fires, let us burn together.
Player: I'm ready - let's dance.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player smiles and bows, taking Wyll's hand. Wyll turns guiding the player into the the center of the imaginary dance floor he was using to practice at the start of the scene.

Wyll releases the player's hand, and the two assume courtly posture oppsite eachother.

Wyll releases the player's hand, and the two assume courtly posture oppsite eachother.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll stomps, assuming a paso doble stance. Perfect lines. Intense. He takes a few rhythmic steps foward, playfully invading the player's space while maintaining eye contact.
Player: Perform a simple cadence.
: True
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player performs a simple dance move and smiles at Wyll.
Wyll: Bravo. Bravo!
Player: It wasn't hard. You just make it look hard.
Wyll: Indeed? Well let's see how you fare with a more - intimate style.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll begins a slower dance and the player follows suit.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The players come closer together until their lips are a hair away of touching.
Player: I'd burn you if I kissed you now, Wyll. No matter how much I want to.
response:
<think>
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking me to determine Wyll's approval of the player's last statement in their conversation. The player says, "I'd burn you if I kissed you now, Wyll. No matter how much I want to." 

First, I need to recall Wyll's character traits. He's a noble, heroic figure with a fiendish pact, so he's conflicted between his duty and personal desires. He's also shown a playful side during the dance, engaging in a romantic or flirtatious interaction. 

The player's line is romantic but also references "burning," which could tie into his infernal connections. However, Wyll's approval guidelines mention that he appreciates valiant acts and kindness, and he's open to genuine interest in his struggles. He dislikes evil plans and wants to avoid infernal ties, but he's not opposed to romantic interest.

The player's statement is flirtatious and shows interest in Wyll despite his devilish nature. Since Wyll is a romanceable character, this kind of interaction would likely be seen as a compliment. The mention of "burning" could be metaphorical, referring to passion, and not necessarily a negative infernal reference. Wyll might appreciate the player's boldness and the romantic gesture, especially since he's already engaged in a dance that's becoming intimate.

Also, considering the context of their previous interactions—practicing dance, playful banter, and moving closer—the player's line is a natural progression of the romantic tension. Wyll's own lines about burning together in Hell's fires earlier indicate he's aware of his infernal ties but is still engaging in this moment of connection. The player's statement doesn't condemn him but rather expresses desire despite his nature, which aligns with Wyll's appreciation for genuine interest.

Therefore, the approval here is positive. The player is showing affection and interest, which Wyll would approve of, even if it's tinged with the theme of burning (which he might interpret as passion rather than something negative).
</think>

conversation:
Wyll: It's funny.
Wyll: As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom.
Wyll: I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army.
Wyll: But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: The poignant tedium of your story?
Wyll: I'd like to think not. The answer is much simpler than that:
Wyll: Time.
Wyll: Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. My eternal soul is at its mercy.
Wyll: It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods.
Wyll: We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us.
Wyll: It even comes for your people in the astral sea. Time may hunt slowly - but it still hunts.
Wyll: Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop it -
Wyll: If just for a moment.
Wyll: Come, let me show you.
Player: Smile and take Wyll's hand.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes Wyll's right hand with their left. Wyll smiles and the scene fades out.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright.
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn.
Wyll: I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough.
Wyll: The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave.
Wyll: Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: A beautiful story. I'm glad you told it to me.
Wyll: I was hoping you'd think so.
Wyll: I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before -
Wyll: And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic.
Wyll: If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight:
Wyll: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?
Player: Yes, yes, yes!
Wyll: Gods. You've made me the happiest soul in all the Realms.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes the acorn from Wyll's hands. He smiles, but remains kneeling.
Narrator: *Your skin flushes and your soul sings as you palm the acorn. Wishing magic, affection, love - whatever the cause, it's as real as the ground beneath you.*
Wyll: Get down here, already. It's time we started our happily-ever-after!

conversation:
Wyll: It's funny.
Wyll: As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom.
Wyll: I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army.
Wyll: But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: The archdevil Zariel?
Wyll: So you'd think. But the right answer is much simpler than that:
Wyll: Time.
Wyll: Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. My eternal soul is at its mercy.
Wyll: It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods.
Wyll: We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us.
Wyll: Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop time -
Wyll: If just for a moment.
Wyll: Come, let me show you.
Player: I can't take your hand without hurting you, but I'll follow where you lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright. NOTE: Karlach CANNOT take Wyll's hand, they shouldn't be touching.See N41
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn.
Wyll: I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough.
Wyll: The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave.
Wyll: Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: Enjoy the view. Enjoy Wyll's quiet company.
Wyll: I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before -
Wyll: And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic.
Wyll: If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight:
Wyll: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?

conversation:
Wyll: It's funny.
Wyll: As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom.
Wyll: I live at the mercy of fiends. A devil's plaything awaiting a future in the Hells.
Wyll: But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: The elder brain?
Wyll: Maybe. But I think the right answer is much simpler than that:
Wyll: Time.
Wyll: Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. My eternal soul is at its mercy.
Wyll: It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods.
Wyll: We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us.
Wyll: It even comes for your people in the astral sea. Time may hunt slowly - but it still hunts.
Wyll: Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop it -
Wyll: If just for a moment.
Wyll: Come, let me show you.
Player: Go on - I'll follow.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright. NOTE: Karlach CANNOT take Wyll's hand, they shouldn't be touching.See N41
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn.
Wyll: I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough.
Wyll: The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave.
Wyll: Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: Seriously? You dragged me out here to look at a tree?
Wyll: I did. But also to see something else:
Wyll: Me.
Wyll: I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before -
Wyll: And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Hail!

Duke Ulder Ravengard: First, you will fell the Absolute. Then, we will rebuild Baldur's Gate, we will take back our city - together.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I will name you Baldur's Gate's newest Grand Duke of the Council. You will be hailed Heart of the Gate.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: But it is true - you are still under the she-devil's thumb...

conversation:
Wyll: It's funny.
Wyll: As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom.
Wyll: I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army.
Wyll: But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: You, yourself?
Wyll: I'd like to think not. The answer is much simpler than that:
Wyll: Time.
Wyll: Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. My eternal soul is at its mercy.
Wyll: It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods.
Wyll: We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us.
Wyll: It even comes for your people in the astral sea. Time may hunt slowly - but it still hunts.
Wyll: Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop it -
Wyll: If just for a moment.
Wyll: Come, let me show you.
Player: I can't take your hand without hurting you, but I'll follow where you lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright. NOTE: Karlach CANNOT take Wyll's hand, they shouldn't be touching.See N41
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn.
Wyll: I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough.
Wyll: The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave.
Wyll: Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: A beautiful story. I'm glad you told it to me.
Wyll: I was hoping you'd think so.
Wyll: I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before -
Wyll: And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic.
Wyll: If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight:
Wyll: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?
Player: Yes, yes, yes!
Wyll: Gods. You've made me the happiest soul in all the Realms.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes the acorn from Wyll's hands. He smiles, but remains kneeling.
Narrator: *Your skin flushes and your soul sings as you palm the acorn. Wishing magic, affection, love - whatever the cause, it's as real as the ground beneath you.*
Wyll: Get down here, already. It's time we started our happily-ever-after!
Wyll: Get down here, already. It's time we started our happily-ever-after!
Player: It's about time. Let's see what the Blade can do with his weapon.
Player: Join Wyll in the grass. Give yourself to him completely.
