conversation:
Wyll: It's funny.
Wyll: As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom.
Wyll: I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army.
Wyll: But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: You, yourself?
Wyll: I'd like to think not. The answer is much simpler than that:
Wyll: Time.
Wyll: Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take.
Wyll: It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods.
Wyll: We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us.
Wyll: Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop time -
Wyll: If just for a moment.
Wyll: Come, let me show you.
Player: Go on - I'll follow.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright. NOTE: Karlach CANNOT take Wyll's hand, they shouldn't be touching.See N41
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn.
Wyll: I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough.
Wyll: The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave.
Wyll: Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: Enjoy the view. Enjoy Wyll's quiet company.
Wyll: I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before -
Wyll: And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic.
Wyll: If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight:
Wyll: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?
Player: I'm not sure. It's a lot to take in.

Wyll: But I'm ready to live a thousand more, if you can bear me.
Player: Yes. I want to be with you, for as long as you'll have me.
Wyll: Gods. You've made me the happiest soul in all the Realms.

conversation:
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Together, Wyll and I will make Baldur's Gate the brightest gem aside the Sword Sea. The Heart of the Gate will prevail.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: As you wish.
Player: Florrick is free. She's gathering allies as we speak.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Tremendous news. She proves as loyal to you as she is to me.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I couldn't bear it if she died by my command. May the Triad guide her steps.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: As you wish.
Player: Tell him about your battle with Ansur.
Wyll: I failed, father. The wyrm is fallen.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: A terrible fate for Ansur, my son. Yet my hopes for the city's future have never been higher.
Wyll: I don't understand.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You and your allies slayed the undead terror that was once the great Ansur. You are stronger than even the great wyrm.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You will be the one to part the storms and lead the people through. You, not Ansur, are the saviour we need.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: First, you will fell the Absolute. Then, we will rebuild Baldur's Gate, we will take back our city - together.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I will name you Baldur's Gate's newest Grand Duke of the Council. You will be hailed Heart of the Gate.
Wyll: Grand Duke? My soul lies with the city. But...
Duke Ulder Ravengard: But what, Wyll?
Wyll: I have slain monsters, faced illithids, guarded the helpless. To be a duke - is this the destiny I've awaited? Is the nobility my calling?
Player: A Grand Duke? You can't turn down an offer like that. Think of the power you'll yield.
Wyll: Courage. Insight. Strategy. Justice. These were the lessons my father taught me.
Wyll: Baldur's Gate is my home, and I am its servant. I will be relentless in my pursuit of the greatest good.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I would sooner die by Mizora's hand than let her endanger the city. I'll figure out a way.
Wyll: The Blade of Frontiers is no more. I will be Wyll Ravengard, son of Ulder, proud Duke of Baldur's Gate.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My son! Together, there is no army we cannot conquer and no wrong we cannot right.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Hail Duke Wyll Ravengard!
Minsc: Duke Wyll Ravengard!
Narrator: *Wyll's courage and enthusiasm warms the air. With him at your side, the road ahead doesn't look so insurmountable.*

conversation:
Wyll: It's funny.
Wyll: As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom.

Wyll: Time.
Wyll: Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take.

Wyll: We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us.

Wyll: It isn't what you think. It never was.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: You gave yourself to the Hells' eternal fires so I might walk free.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: I didn't despair because the city has a secret guardian, a wyrm that sleeps beneath. He can be called upon in times of great need.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: This is such a time. You've been trained in the ways of the great champions and proven to be one of them. The wyrm will answer your call. You must seek him out.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: This is no ordinary dragon.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: The wyrm goes by many names. Ansur. The Waiting Storm. The Heart of the Gate.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: He promised Balduran he'd protect the city if ever its existence was threatened. But just the once.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Since then, the city has faced countless threats, but we always overcame. There was never a need to call on the wyrm - until now.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: The Absolute is the greatest threat Baldur's Gate ever faced. The wyrm must be awakened - and the task falls to you.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Take this - 'The Legend of Ansur'. An ancient epic, ill-remembered, dismissed as a mere tale.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Let it set the path before you.
